Award.AwardTitle: Increasing Access and Diversity in STEM Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The S-STEM project at Hagerstown Community College(HCC) serves students in a variety of STEM disciplines and students in a number of degree programs are eligible for S-STEM. HCC coordinates efforts through the PI and two division chairs to ensure that scholarships are awarded equitably and efficiently, while still involving program coordinators and lead faculty members in scholarship decisions.

Project objectives include raising S-STEM full-time enrollment rates by 30% and increasing retention rates for S-STEM students (compared to students in S-STEM-eligible majors in the past) by 20%. HCC also seeks to improve completion/transfer rates and the percentage of full-time STEM degree program students who are members of minority groups or female. Ambitious targets specify high rates at which S-STEM graduates will either find employment in a field related to S-STEM or enroll at a four-year institution within one year of graduation. In order to ensure that HCC achieves its goals, the college is implementing "intrusive" S-STEM-specific advising, an S-STEM one-credit seminar required for all awardees, and additional activities such as an STEM club, field trips, and an S-STEM scholar recognition ceremony. HCC works to increase the number of internship sites and four-year articulation agreements available to S-STEM students; the project also provides a limited number of scholarships for students who have graduated from HCC and have transferred to a four-year college or university.

HCC's project is intellectually meritorious because it examines the effects of supports such as scholarships and academic supports on student enrollment, retention, completion, and success. The project evaluation plan is designed not just to measure whether activities occur, but also whether they are effective. HCC is also surveying students to determine how they learned about the S-STEM program and to identify which supports are most crucial to their success.

The greatest impact of this project is expected to be demonstrated through projected increases in enrollment, retention, and completion rates of students, particularly underrepresented students, in STEM programs in HCC's Appalachian service area. Data indicate that a very low percentage of adults (~15%) in the region have bachelor's degrees, compared to 35.7% for Maryland as a whole and 28.6% in the nation. Therefore, the project is particularly crucial for achieving local, regional, and national goals of assisting more students to complete degrees and transfer to further baccalaureate studies and/or immediately join the workforce.

ProgramReference.Text: Math Success in First 2 Years of College

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of Hagerstown Community College's S-STEM grant was to increase the number of students completing STEM degrees and preparing for STEM-related jobs. The S-STEM grant allowed Hagerstown Community College (HCC) to award scholarships to 111 students ranging from 1 to 4 semesters. By requiring students to be full-time, ninety-five percent of our scholar recipients were able to complete their degree within six semesters.

Scholarships were granted based on both demonstrated academic talent and financial need. During the five-year period covered by the grant, the college experienced an overall decline in full-time enrollment.  However, HCC experienced an overall increase of full-time S-STEM majors as indicated by Table 1.

The second goal of the S-STEM grant was to increase the number of female and minority students in STEM fields. Of the 111 scholarship recipients, 39.6% were female and 24.3% self-identified with minority status.  These two percentages were slightly greater than the general College percentage of females and minority students in STEM fields, which ranged between 21.5-30.5% for females and 19.6-24.7% for minorities.

The third goal of the grant was to increase STEM transfer into a four-year institution or related work field within twelve months of graduating. Sixty-four out of the 111 S-STEM scholarship recipients graduated HCC during their tenure at HCC. Of these graduating students, eighty-five percent transferred to a four-year institution within their STEM major or entered the work force in a related STEM field. To help encourage further education at a four-year institute, the HCC S-STEM grant committee awarded eleven transfer scholarships to students transferring into a STEM field at a four-year institution.

An S-STEM seminar course was created to develop a cohort of students to encompass the large academic and social diversity among the S-STEM grant recipients.  The S-STEM seminar included a different theme each semester and rotated among the following topics:  Nobel Prize Winning Concepts, Robotics, Energy, and Innovative Ideas. Each theme incorporated the various majors with guest speakers from industry, other universities and within HCC's own faculty base. In addition to guest speakers, students over the course of five years answered critical thinking questions on various scientific articles or wrote a critical thinking paper on our themed seminar topic. Team work and collaboration were integral to the student projects, with students giving group presentations on the semester's themed topic. The seminar also included a field trip to either an industrial site which involved STEM careers or nearby university for a transfer visit.

To help students navigate their journey at HCC, the grant supported an S-STEM advisor that met with students monthly, creating a course schedule that would allow students to graduate HCC and transfer credits to their transfer institution. A database was created to help the S-STEM advisor and the grant's PI to assist students with planning schedules, taking notes on advising meetings and reporting information on the NSF reporting site.

Each spring, prior to HCC's graduation, S-STEM scholarship recipients attended an S-STEM Recognition Ceremony. The Ceremony included a keynote speaker discussing their particular journey to an S-STEM career. In addition, two graduating S-STEM scholarship recipients spoke about how the S-STEM scholarship helped them in achieving a degree in a STEM field or with STEM-related job opportunities. During this ceremony S-STEM scholarship recipients were recognized for either completing their degree or for earning the scholarship. Lastly, transfer scholarships were awarded to S-STEM scholarship recipients who would be completing their STEM degrees at a four-year institute.

In addition, over the course of this five year grant, HCC

  • introduced Environmental Science as a new Associate of Science degree;
  • crafted 18 new articulation agreements with Bowie State University, Capital College, Capital Technical University, Frostburg State University, University of Maryland-College Park, University of Maryland University College, Shepherd University
  • coordinated with 62 advisory committees;
  • added 50 new internship sites for STEM majors.

Western Maryland is an area where many students do not reach their potential for educational attainment. Only 23.2% of the populace have at least an associate degree, compared to 36.6% in the U.S. as a whole. The S-STEM grant impacted this community by providing scholarships to students who may otherwise not have been able to attend HCC full-time. The grant provided an opportunity for students to complete their degrees within 4 to 6 semesters and either enter the workforce or transfer to four-year degree programs.
